sec.p: The sudden increase of HRM-related service providers is closely related to the organizational restructuring after the 1997 crisis, increased adoption of new HRM systems characterized as performance-based annual pay and workforce flexibility, and frequent institutional changes in terms of labor laws. All these new environments have made it difficult for firms to assume all these activities by themselves. The problem arises when firms lose their control over trends and solely depend on outside consulting firms for certain activities; this in turn makes the diffusion of certain types of HRM systems much easier and more widespread. Thus, the social upheaval created conditions in which many institutional arrangements have changed, which in turn has led to certain types of HRM approaches becoming taken for granted.

sec.title: Recipient human capital
sec.p: Recipient human capital is another critical factor in the rapid diffusion of management ideologies and practices because it contributes to the design of institutional arrangements, which in turn become templates facilitating global diffusion (Drori et al., 2006). As for institutional factors, most faculty members of major business schools have earned their PhD degrees from universities in the US. For example, in the three major business schools in Korea, 152 (91%) of 166 faculty members had earned their PhD degrees from US institutions as of 2006.6 Although not all these faculty members accept the American style of management, they are well acquainted with American faculty and management style. If they are not all champions of the American style of management, they are at least less likely to be foes of it. These faculty members, especially in major schools, have been actively involved in business education, through which they serve as the ‘academic clergy’ of certain types of management styles. Just as international organizations both preach and practice certain modes of ideologies and practices (Drori et al., 2006), business schools not only preach certain styles of management, but also practice the style they teach by adopting internal competition and performance-based promotions.

Before the 1997 financial crisis, large Korean corporations requested faculty members of the major business schools to carry out their management consulting projects. However, in the post-crisis period, management began changing this tradition. Korean firms instead have given their consulting projects to professional consulting firms, especially globally recognized big companies such as McKinsey & Company. Korean firms have also sent their management staff to major universities in Western countries and invited foreign scholars for business education. Beyond the company level, the national economy itself has also been the object of consulting (e.g. Korea Report by Booz-Allen & Hamilton Inc., 1997; McKinsey Report on Reinventing Korea by McKinsey & Company, 1998).

sec.title: Local firms: Learners of norms
sec.p: Korean management used the 1997 crisis as a chance to legitimize its own management ideologies. Benchmarking best practices and satisfying global standards were Korean firms’ two most critical driving forces.

During the initial economic development period, management in Korean firms developed a ‘late-comer complex’, the sense of inferiority as a firm in a country engaged in economic development in the late time. This made management search continually for the ‘advanced techniques’ of competitive companies in economically advanced countries. This attitude changed little even after some big corporations produced some of the top products in the world. In addition, the ideological worldview of Korean professional management was less clearly implemented, because the founders of the firms controlled their firms and their thinking took precedence. All these factors together helped to create a social norm of a ‘change-is-good’ mentality.

Firms were aggressively involved in benchmarking activities. For example, one major electronics company in Korea recklessly spent money for benchmarking purposes. After the 1997 financial crisis, the company managers visited over 50 major companies around the world, including General Electric, IBM, HP, Sony, Philips, Intel, Nokia, JPMorgan, ING Group, Toyota, and Ericsson.

The benchmarking process can be nicely explained by the conformity of actors to social norms, defined as ‘shared perceptions of appropriate behavior that possess the power to induce people to act publicly in ways that deviate from their private inclinations’ (Miller, 1999: 1056). Although benchmarking activities are not necessarily advantageous, firms tend to perceive that other firms are actively involved in benchmarking best practices and global standards, which motivates management to become involved in benchmarking activities. Now the benchmarking process has become a social norm from which firms are reluctant to deviate due to their fear of becoming pace-losers.

The adoption of new policies and practices by leading companies has enabled them to gain legitimacy, and those policies and practices have in turn become the pattern-setters for other companies. As more major companies have adopted those orientations, the speed of diffusion has accelerated. One CEO of a foreign consulting firm mentioned that Korea is a perfect testing ground for newly created management techniques, because when one firm adopts a new program, it rapidly spreads to almost all major companies in very short period of time. Two examples are relevant here.

The first example is about ‘war for talent’, a typical management arrangement for grouping of workers. Samsung pronounced it should engage in a war for talent. With regard to the top talent management, before the 1997 financial crisis, few companies in Korea used the program. However, the percentage of listed companies that adopted such a program drastically increased from 27.05% in 2003 to 30.0% in 2004, and then to 64.8% in 2006 (Kim, 2010). These data are for higher-end employees.

LG Electronics declared it had adopted ‘performance orientation’ as the backbone of its HRM system. To assess the changes in performance-based approach, we looked into how much attention it has gained from the public. For this, using the information retrieval system (www.kinds.or.kr) of the Korea Press Foundation, we checked how many times the term ‘performance orientation’ of HRM occurred in the national daily newspapers per year (see Figure 2). The number of occurrences of the term in the newspapers was less than 40 before 1998. It constantly increased and, as a result, the average has increased from 15.7 (1991–1997) to 131.4 (1998–2010). This increase in frequency reflects the fact that the performance orientation of Korean HRM has been paid much attention by companies as well as by the public.

caption.p: Occurrence of the term ‘performance orientation’ in the national daily newspapers.

sec.p: This process has been accelerated further by other features of Korean firms, such as speed management, crisis management, organization-wide experiment with new approaches, and the rapid diffusion tradition of management innovation techniques. Firms have often experimented with new management techniques and practices covering the whole organization, rather than just part of the organization to test their efficacy. ‘Speed’ has become a key term in Korean management. Since the mid-1980s, Korean firms have experimented with various ‘new’ management approaches (Kim and Bae, 2004), including TQM, BPR (Lee and Sohn, 2001), team-based work systems (Lee and Kim, 1999), BSC, 6-sigma, management transparency (Han and Bae, 2001), and so on. The aforementioned institutional forces explain the adoption and diffusion of these new approaches. The studies show that firms tend to adopt new approaches by mimicking the actions of the leading companies. Downsizing is not an exception in this regard, not only in the US (McKinley et al., 1995) but also in Korea.

sec.title: Individual actors: Facilitators or obstructers?
sec.p: Since the self-fulfilling process involves the change of ideologies and social norms, the role and influence of individual actors in the socio-political processes are also critical at the micro level. Individual actors may include individual employees, HRM managers, labor unions, and so on. It is beyond the scope of this article to cover all the details of the socio-political processes of each actor. It would suffice to briefly cover the two forces: the driving force facilitating the diffusion of new approaches and the force of resistance hindering the process.

First, until recently, the driving force of global diffusion typically came from top management and human resource (HR) managers. Their efforts included conducting benchmarking activities, holding global HR conferences, and attending major HRM-related conferences. When major large corporations found a company with more progressive HRM practices, they allowed their managers to visit that firm regardless of country of origin or type of industry. Each benchmarking activity was pursued by a team of two to seven members for anywhere from a few hours to several days. This kind of activity continued until around the year 2005. After that time, most Korean firms stopped their benchmarking efforts. Large Korean multinationals also hold global HRM conferences every year. HRM directors from all over the world get together at these conferences to share HR-related knowledge. In addition, many major Korean companies also send their HRM managers to major HRM-related conferences such as the SHRM (the Society for Human Resource Management) Annual Conference and the ASTD (the American Society for Training & Development) International Conference.

However, these efforts of HRM managers could not be institutionalized without resistance from unions and individual actors. Two critical areas that encountered strong resistance were the individual performance-based approach vis-à-vis the seniority-based one and employment flexibility vis-à-vis employment security. While the first issue was not overly problematic, the second issue was critical. Downsizing, utilizing contingent workers, early retirement were all good examples of numerical flexibility. The case of the Hyundai Motor Company was a typical example that went through the complicated socio-political processes (Rowley and Bae, 2002). The company reduced its workforce of 45,000 to about 35,000 in 1998 through 277 dismissals, 7226 voluntary retirements, and about 2000 layoffs for temporary workers. Its restructuring and downsizing plans generated huge costs. The original plan to dismiss 4830 ended up being only 277 with many illegal strikes and conflicts during the year of 1998, costing Hyundai about US$750m of revenue and its suppliers some US$600m. This example clearly shows that the diffusion process was not smoothly progressed at least at the early stage. As Kostova (1999) claimed, institutionalization has both implementation and internalization processes. In the case of Korean firms, the formal implementation of certain practices should be followed by the internalization process. The internalization process can be achieved when individual actors have commitment to, satisfaction with, and psychological ownership of, newly adopted HRM practices (Bae and Rowley, 2001; Kostova, 1999). The progress of the internalization process, the high level of crisis at that time, and the efforts of HRM managers all combined to lower the resistance level of both local firms and employees.

In sum, the self-fulfilling process at a global level explains the evolution of HRM in Korea. The employment relationship has shifted from a paternalistic model to a market-like model featuring internal competition, wide pay differential, and performance orientation. All these new approaches were once unfamiliar to Korean firms but have now become socially acceptable norms. Once they are legitimized, the new approaches perpetuate themselves. This new HRM model has now created conditions through institutional arrangements, languages, and assumptions that make them even more likely to develop (Ferraro et al., 2005). In this diffusion process, international organizations, local institutions, firms, and individual actors have played their particular roles, while the 1997 financial crisis provided the social climate that has made the global diffusion much easier.

sec.title: Discussion and implications
sec.p: We conceptualized the institutional theory of diffusion as a phenomenon of the self-fulfilling process. This process was applied to the evolution of Korean HRM. We argued that the content of diffusion contained management ideology, especially neoliberalistic approach. Based on our findings, we make several points.

First, the contents and timing of management diffusion in emerging economies or recently economically developed countries such as Korea are quite different from those of Western developed countries. Organization and employment management ideologies and rhetoric have historically undergone change (Abrahamson, 1997; Barley and Kunda, 1992; De Greene, 1988; Gill and Whittle, 1993). Thus far, five rhetorics (industrial betterment, scientific management, welfare capitalism/human relations, systems rationalism, and organizational culture) have been suggested, at least in the US; these rhetorics can be further classified into two classes: rational rhetorics and normative rhetorics (Abrahamson, 1997; Barley and Kunda, 1992). It is suggested that these two rhetorics are cyclical in nature, alternating between swings of the pendulum. The pendulum swing thesis is quite intuitive in understanding the changes in management ideologies and rhetorics in the US.

Unlike the long-wave thesis of the pendulum swing of managerial rhetoric in the developed economies (Abrahamson, 1997; Ayres, 1990; Kleinknecht, 1987; Tylecote, 1994), Korea is experiencing the short-wave pendulum. As a late-comer, Korea began its economic development only in the early 1960s. The two decades of rapid economic development in the 1970s and 1980s and two major turning points in 1987 and 1997 bring shorter cycles within the long-wave trends of Western economies.

Second, as for the driving forces behind the emergence of new waves, the diffusion (learning) process in an emerging economy involves a complex set of developmental dynamics that centre on the work of the State and particular industrial groups. The efforts of these agents is mediated by regional economic ‘shocks’ and local political machinations. Barley and Kunda (1992: 392) suggested that one might postulate that culture has set the substantive and structural boundaries within which managerial discourse has developed but that economic forces have determined when new surges of theorizing occurred. However, at a global level, an employment management rhetoric is affected not only by cultural ideologies and economic forces within the country, but also by benchmarking processes in terms of advanced technologies and management practices. Economic forerunners and followers have gone different routes in shaping their employment management rhetorics. Economic late-comers have had more dynamic and complex interactions between their national traditional ideologies and Western ideologies. Some conflict between national cultural traditions and newly adopted foreign ideologies is to be expected. Before Korean firms became deeply involved in global businesses, the adoption of Western rhetorics and management practices took longer and experienced a time lag. But since Korean firms have become more globalized, real-time benchmarking has developed and has been more directly influenced by the management rhetorics and practices of other countries.

Finally, the relationship between technological innovation and organizational innovation found in Western firms (Abrahamson, 1997; De Greene, 1988) does not match well with Korea. The process of catch-up by Korean firms started with their ‘imitating’ firms in economically advanced countries, and progressed through ‘creative imitation’ to ‘innovation’ (Kim, 1997). Different phases of the learning and innovation process may require different management arrangements, although causality is not clear. Furthermore, local conditions also intervene and challenge the importation of particular practices (e.g. imported HRM) which had a mixed impact on innovation performance. Certain rhetoric of employment management does not generate desirable technological innovation. Recent changes in HRM toward a more market-like employment relationship have caused innovation to deteriorate. A case study on an R&D center of LG Electronics showed that a performance-based HRM system generated higher innovation performance on average, but the proportion of exploratory innovation vis-à-vis exploitative innovation decreased (Bae and Park, 2005).

From the findings and discussion, we can derive several implications. First, although the global learning process is quite prevalent these days, global learning activities should be very cautious by prudently considering country-specific context. Ferraro et al. (2005: 17) argued that ‘despite cultural differences and different rates of acceptance, we would also expect to find that, over time, the language and assumptions of economics are indeed diffusing globally’. In addition, they also suggested pursuing historical studies that focus on the evolution of management practices as an avenue of future research. This analysis of the evolution of Korean HRM partly reflects their argument. Judging from these observations, best management practices would not be ‘best’ for every country all the time. Each country may learn quite country-specific and time-specific contents from another country. In this article, we argue that Korean firms adopted American-style management practices in the late 1990s and early 2000s. Even though every country has something to learn from other countries, it is unwise to discard all the merits of the existing paradigm, which is based on the ethos of local people (Bae and Rowley, 2001).

Second, organizational changes appear to undergo a dialectical movement from one extreme (i.e. a paternalistic model) to another (i.e. a market-like model), rather than directly moving toward a synthesis by resolving some shortcomings of the previous model and adding other needed features. Since ‘the ideology sows the seeds of its own destruction’ (Barley and Kunda, 1992: 392), the current HRM mode in Korea appears inadequate, as we observe many inconsistencies within it. If it is necessary to take the antithesis, one simple lesson is keeping the shortcomings of it in mind. Many Korean corporations experimented with the market-like employment relationship over the past 10 years and realized that it went too far. Rebuilding lost values, such as trust, would take much longer than destroying them.

Finally, another important implication of this article is that the global diffusion process of market-like employment management has become self-fulfilling at a global level. This self-fulfilling process occurs through the influence of international organizations such as the IMF, with the facilitation of local institutions, when a country encounters a crisis, such as the 1997 financial crisis in Korea. Local firms also become actively involved in the process when they benchmark best practices to meet global standards. Once these new languages and assumptions, previously rejected by many stakeholders, obtain legitimacy and become socially accepted, the diffusion is greatly accelerated and is afterwards taken for granted. However, generally accepted ideologies and social norms do not necessarily mean they are right. Self-fulfilling processes occur regardless of whether the contents are true. It requires discernment on the part of management when it adopts new management practices. Labor market flexibility is a prime case in point.

The Korean Government and many large corporations thought the adoption of labor market flexibility was a critical factor for company competitiveness. We can observe similar debates in some European countries, the UK, and Australia (Bae and Rowley, 2001). For example, the phenomenon whereby Korean firms were adapting to neoliberalism by adopting a dual approach was witnessed in the UK in the 1980s (Atkinson, 1985; Atkinson and Gregory, 1986; Atkinson and Meager, 1986).7 The core-periphery model was subject to considerable criticism (e.g. Pollert, 1988, 1991): the current employment modes are ‘far more complex and uneven lines than this polarization’ (Pollert, 1988: 281). There were also some qualified defenses such as arguing that we need to understand the model at a political level with a different view of strategy (i.e. ‘patterns’ rather than ‘plans’) (e.g. Procter et al., 1994). In addition, there have been initiatives by the European Union such as ‘flexicurity’ to counter this model by enhancing both flexibility of the firm and labor market on the one hand, and security of employment and income on the other, all of which promote security for contingent workers (European Commission, 2006, 2007). From these arguments, Korean firms may learn a lesson: a veneer of legitimacy does not resolve all current and emerging issues. If the experiences of Korean firms over the past decade have not been just a simplistic fad, wisdom based on evidence and continuing debate is called for.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article analyzed the evolution of Korean HRM using the framework of self-fulfilling prophecy and the institutional theory of diffusion. These perspectives underpin the global learning process. Contingent upon dynamic interactions among international institutions and local institutions, the nature, contents, timing, and ways of global learning become quite different from the existing literature on those of Western countries. Therefore, we argue that we regard Barley and Kunda’s (1992) work as a locality study (i.e. US-based argument), and that other locality studies such as this article require us to theorize a much stronger role for other agents in the process of diffusion. This line of argument departs substantially from the currently dominant framework of institutional determinism. Rather, we argue that we need to incorporate the proactive roles of local agents, such as government, corporate groups, business schools, and consulting firms, into the framework of the global learning process. This ‘strong agency’ perspective (Kostova et al., 2008) provides rich explanation for the global diffusion process.

However, the choice of managerial rhetoric seems to be highly contingent upon the moderating role of local economic conditions such as financial shock. The 1997 financial crisis put the local agents under high pressure for survival. Given limited choices and a sense of urgency, rapid global diffusion process occurred without much reflection. In this situation, the strong agency roles with a homogenous perspective expedite global learning process toward a rather dominant management ideology at the time.

In sum, this study makes a contribution to the literature of both institutional theory and organizational learning theory by focusing on the global learning/diffusion of management discourse which highlights the importance of local or regional dynamics (e.g. state intervention, globalization of business groups, economic shocks and variable impact of some practices).
